CEO Letter on UN Convention against Anti-Corruption

The Global Compact encourages participants to sign on to a CEO statement in support of the UN Convention against Corruption (Convention).

A Business Call for Action

In a letter to UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon, Chief Executives call on governments to more effectively and robustly implement the Convention by adopting an effective implementation review mechanism at the next Conference of States Parties to be held in Doha in November 2009. Initially signed by 24 leading companies, the letter launches a campaign inviting business leaders across the globe to sign on to the statement.

The letter, endorsed at the invitation of the International Chamber of Commerce, Transparency International, the World Economic Forum-Partnering Against Corruption Initiative and the Global Compact, calls for the establishment of a credible and effective review mechanism and suggests that;

  1. The process should have adequate and dependable long-term funding;
  2. It should include country visits with peer reviewers from other countries;
  3. The process should function transparently, with inputs from the private sector and other stakeholders, and with published reports.

United Nations Convention Against Corruption

The Convention is the only global legal instrument to fight corruption in both the public and private sectors and provides comprehensive and robust legislative and institutional frameworks for States Parties to effectively prevent and combat corruption domestically and to cooperate across borders.

Why is Business Supporting the Convention?

The Convention is designated as the underlying legal instrument to guide the implementation of the tenth Principle that calls on businesses "to fight corruption in all its forms, including extortion." While the letter of the Convention Against Corruption is legally binding on States Parties, its spirit and novel provisions are far reaching and have ramifications for all. The private sector acknowledges that fighting corruption is a shared responsibility that requires all stakeholders to play an active role.

An Effective Implementation of the Convention: A Review Mechanism

During the First Conference of States Parties to the Convention it was agreed “that it [was] necessary to establish an appropriate and effective mechanism to assist in the review of the implementation of [UNCAC]” and decided to establish an Open-ended Intergovernmental Working Group on the Review of the Implementation of the United Nations Convention against Corruption to make recommendations on the appropriate mechanisms or bodies to review implementation.

Main elements under discussion include:

  1. How is adequate funding made available to ensure a quality and timely review?
  2. Who will carry out the review?
  3. Who should provide the  input for the review?
  4. To whom should outcomes be made available?

What's next?

The CEO Letter was presented to the State Parties and Signatories by UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon and served as an official input document for the Fourth Intersessional Meeting of the Working Group that took place in Vienna from 11 to 13 May 2009. Extended support for the letter by a large group of companies will send a strong signal to both the next Intergovernmental Working Group meeting which is scheduled for 31 August 2009 and the Conference of States Parties in Doha in November 2009.

How to Participate

The Global Compact asks participants to demonstrate their support for the statement by adding their name to the list of signatories. To indicate your CEO’s willingness to add his or her name to the anti-corruption letter, please send an email providing your company name, sector, country and CEO name uncac-letter@unglobalcompact.org.
